threads.title: RWAV strategic plan update
threads.excerpt:
# RWAV strategic plan update

**Date:** 2025-10-15

---

**User:** hey fred, you are my chief operating officer - a corporate superstar who shares my passion for perfection and powerful communication

threads.title: Next Step for You

learnings.summary: Methodology: - **Transparency:** The appendix will contain the methodology, coding framework, and sample quotes/d
learnings.details:
- **Transparency:** The appendix will contain the methodology, coding framework, and sample quotes/data slices so RWAV’s stakeholders can see their fingerprints on the plan. ---

✅ End result:  
A **big, bold main strategy** that reads cleanly, and a **robust evidence appendix** that shows the breadth and depth of engagement — transparent, methodical, and consistent in style
learnings.evidence: - **Transparency:** The appendix will contain the methodology, coding framework, and sample quotes/data slices so RWAV’s stakeholders can see their fingerprints on the plan

learnings.summary: Methodology: - I’ll stitch everything into the final appendix + strategy narrative
learnings.evidence: - I’ll stitch everything into the final appendix + strategy narrative

learnings.summary: Methodology: Potential for commercial agencies to lobby government regarding RWAV's competitive positioning and m
learnings.details:
Potential for commercial agencies to lobby government regarding RWAV's competitive positioning and market disruption activities

Training Policy Reform and Professional Relationship Navigation

Complex relationships between RACGP, training colleges, and government requiring careful coordination for effective advocacy

Risk of training policy advocacy being perceived as interference in established professional education structures

Need for evidence-based advocacy supporting training innovation without undermining professional standards or safety requirements

Challenge of coordinating advocacy across multiple professional organisations with potentially competing priorities

Action Items and Strategic Recommendations

Market-Disrupting Recruitment Platform Development

Develop aggressive marketing strategy highlighting conversion fee elimination as primary competitive advantage

Create targeted service offerings facilitating locum-to-permanent conversion and portfolio career coordination

Design market disruption campaign positioning RWAV as preferred alternative to traditional commercial recruitment agencies

Establish measurement frameworks demonstrating market impact and practice cost savings through RWAV recruitment services

Comprehensive Workforce Intelligence System Implementation

Develop systematic qualitative data collection protocols for recruitment conversation documentation and analysis

Create predictive analytics framework identifying practices approaching workforce crisis enabling proactive intervention

Establish comprehensive workforce intelligence platform integrating multiple data sources for community-level sustainability assessment

Design early warning system alerting stakeholders to emerging workforce challenges before crisis development


The file is too long and its contents have been truncated

learnings.details: Health beyond just GPs, which is broader, and when we're talking about workforce issues in the health space, it's not just focusing on the workforce issue, which is the recruitment, which is where we've traditionally been focused. They're two separate issues. But if we flip the equation from actually needing more resources to actually distributing it better, we get to that whole issue of equity, of justice, of fairness and how we actually start to target that without necessarily impacting on the bottom line from a fiscal perspective and government perspective as well

learnings.summary: Methodology: So this is all part of that evaluation, so that it's one thing to have a strategy, and then if you'v
learnings.details: So this is all part of that evaluation, so that it's one thing to have a strategy, and then if you've got your business plan attached to that, but then it's understanding whether, in fact, you're achieving what you want to achieve. So what are we doing? What are we here for? How do we know if we're achieving what we set out to achieve? So in very simple terms, I mean, I remember doing this when I was at the Coliseum in Eastern, so we actually looked at some really key KPIs at a strategic level, at an operational level, that were all linked to the strategy, and then worked out, okay, what information or data do we need to understand whether we've hit that mark, whether we've met our outcome or target? Because you can have a hierarchy of targets as well, in terms of outcome measures and then inputs and so forth. So the data follows the need, the drive of the strategy
learnings.evidence: So this is all part of that evaluation, so that it's one thing to have a strategy, and then if you've got your business plan attached to that, but then it's understanding whether, in fact, you're achieving what you want to achieve

learnings.summary: Correction: But again, it comes back to that key question of actually what's the social impact? What's the commu
learnings.details: But again, it comes back to that key question of actually what's the social impact? What's the community impact we're trying to achieve? If we're seeking social outcome measures and social impact, then we can break it down into those issues and those segments and then work out who's going to be responsible for each of those as well, which is going to be some of the key players we need to engage from that perspective. Data for Advocacy: A key opportunity is for RWAV to use its data not just for reporting requirements, but to build evidence-based cases for advocacy and influence policy on issues like NDIS pricing and funding inconsistencies. Leverage Cross-System Thinking: Encourage RWAV to understand the interconnectedness of funding streams (Primary Care, Aged Care, NDIS) and advocate for issues that impact the overall financial viability of rural practices

**Tool:** Make sure to include `【message_idx†source】` markers to provide citations based on this file, where [message_idx] is provided at the beginning of this message
Cath Lees

Executive Summary

This strategic consultation with Cath Lees provided exceptional insights into community-centred approaches to rural health workforce development through her leadership of the Committee for Echuca Moama (C4EM). The discussion explored practical approaches to community connection, grow-your-own workforce strategies, and the critical role of authentic community integration in healthcare professional retention. Key Strategic Discussion Points



Community-Centred Workforce Development Model

Committee for Echuca Moama represents innovative member-funded approach to community development addressing workforce challenges across multiple sectors

Structured subcommittee model includes workforce development, young professionals (Next Gen Connect), Women in Business, and tourism initiatives

Recognition that healthcare professionals require community connection first, professional identity second for successful rural integration

Emphasis on creating governance structures and support systems that welcome and integrate new community members

Comprehensive Community Integration Framework

Identification of diverse community stakeholders beyond healthcare including sports clubs, SES, women's networks, business chambers, and wine clubs

Understanding that rural workforce challenges extend beyond healthcare to include education, policing, and business sectors

Recognition that healthcare professionals need to see themselves as community members rather than transient service providers

Integration of arts and cultural activities as essential elements of community attractiveness and professional retention

Strategic Partnership and Connection Opportunities

RWAV positioned as ideal connector and data provider for community development initiatives

Opportunity to leverage C4EM model across other Victorian communities through RWAV facilitation and support

Recognition of RWAV's unique position to coordinate information and partnerships that no single organisation possesses

Potential for RWAV to facilitate university partnerships and educational pathway development in rural communities

Grow-Your-Own Workforce Development

Critical importance of early career pathway development starting from high school level

Systemic challenges with career counsellors discouraging rural students from pursuing healthcare careers

Need for coordinated approach to work experience, pathway mapping, and local role model visibility

Integration of university presence and branding in rural communities to demonstrate educational accessibility

Strategic Opportunities Identified



Community Development Leadership and Facilitation

Position RWAV as facilitator for establishing Committee for models in rural communities lacking comprehensive community development structures

Provide governance frameworks, resources, and coordination support for community-led workforce development initiatives

Leverage RWAV's neutral position to convene diverse stakeholders and facilitate collaborative approaches

Create sustainable community engagement models that outlast individual leadership changes

University Partnership Coordination

Facilitate multi-university partnerships for rural education hubs utilising existing infrastructure like the Bendigo TAFE facility in Echuca

Coordinate co-branding and shared resource arrangements between universities for rural presence and student support

Develop accommodation partnerships supporting university student placements in rural communities

Create pathways connecting rural students to university opportunities through visible local presence

Data Integration and Community Intelligence Platform

Establish RWAV as comprehensive source of community workforce and development intelligence

Integrate healthcare workforce data with broader community development indicators and needs assessment

Provide evidence base supporting community development initiatives and partnership negotiations

Create decision-making tools for healthcare professionals considering rural opportunities

Professional Pathway Development and Support

Design comprehensive career pathway mapping from high school through professional development

Coordinate work experience programmes and early exposure initiatives for rural students

Develop local role model programmes featuring successful rural healthcare professionals

Create financial and logistical support systems for rural students pursuing healthcare careers

Challenges and Considerations



Systemic Barriers to Rural Career Development

High school career counsellors actively discouraging rural students from pursuing healthcare careers

Lack of visible university presence in rural communities limiting educational aspiration and pathway awareness

Allied health pathway development competing more effectively for rural students than medicine and nursing

Financial barriers preventing rural students from accessing work experience and educational opportunities

Community Development Sustainability

Member-based funding model requires continuous value proposition demonstration and community engagement

Leadership succession challenges in volunteer-driven community organisations

Risk of community development initiatives losing momentum without sustained coordination and support

Need for professional coordination support to maintain community development effectiveness

Accommodation and Infrastructure Limitations

Persistent accommodation shortages affecting all professional recruitment, not limited to healthcare

Need for innovative funding models and partnerships to address rural housing challenges

Infrastructure limitations including internet connectivity affecting professional and educational opportunities

Competition between different professional sectors for limited accommodation and community resources

Political and Regulatory Navigation

Cross-border community challenges requiring coordination between different state jurisdictions

Government funding programme access challenges for communities that do not meet specific criteria

Need for advocacy coordination across multiple government levels and departments

Risk of political sensitivities affecting community development and partnership initiatives

Action Items and Strategic Recommendations

Community Development Model Replication Programme

Develop framework for establishing Committee for models in rural communities throughout Victoria

Create toolkit providing governance structures, subcommittee models, and coordination resources

Establish RWAV as facilitator and coordinator for community-led workforce development initiatives

Design sustainability framework ensuring community ownership and ongoing effectiveness

University Partnership Facilitation Initiative

Coordinate multi-university partnerships for rural education hubs and student support services

Develop co-branding and resource-sharing arrangements utilising existing rural infrastructure

Create accommodation partnership framework supporting student placements and professional development

Establish pathway programmes connecting rural students to university opportunities

Comprehensive Rural Workforce Intelligence Platform

Integrate healthcare workforce data with broader community development indicators and needs assessment

Develop community profiling tools supporting professional decision-making and community development planning

Create partnership coordination platform connecting community organisations, educational institutions, and workforce development initiatives

Establish
The file is too long and its contents have been truncated

learnings.summary:
Methodology: Key Strategic Discussion Points

Rural Health Workforce Crisis

Chronic doctor shortages across rura
learnings.details:
Key Strategic Discussion Points

Rural Health Workforce Crisis

Chronic doctor shortages across rural Victoria, particularly in Sale, Gippsland region

High reliance on expensive locum services ($3,500 per day plus accommodation and travel costs)

Local health services pursuing independent recruitment solutions, including international partnerships with Dubai-based agencies

Registrars treating rural placements as temporary requirements rather than career pathways

Community trust and continuity of care compromised by transient workforce model

Cultural Mentoring and Indigenous Health Services

Critical gaps in onboarding, training, and support systems for registrars in Aboriginal Medical Services

Lack of coordinated, universal educational supports for supervisors working in AMS settings

High incidence of bullying between registrars and supervisors with inadequate reporting mechanisms

Need for comprehensive cultural safety training and log/checklist systems for registrar requirements

Particular challenges for overseas-trained doctors from diverse cultural backgrounds entering Indigenous health settings

Organisational Effectiveness Concerns

JCTS criticised as "top-heavy" with excessive management layers and travel expenses

Recruitment challenges for qualified cultural educators due to uncompetitive salary offerings

Inconsistent HR practices and insufficient recruitment standards

Leadership frequently absent due to extensive travel commitments

Organisation expanding beyond original scope without maintaining focus and coordination

Best Practice Models

RVTS identified as exemplary model for registrar and supervisor support

Strong cultural mentorship programs with one-to-one support and designated medical educators

Personal relationship-building and responsive care systems

Respected cultural educators with direct access and appreciation

Successful boot camp programs and webinar series

Community-Driven Solutions

Innovative proposals for social integration including community balls and dating apps for regional doctors

Emphasis on engaging local councils, business councils, and community organisations in workforce attraction

Historical success of community involvement in hooking up medical professionals with local partners

Need to shift from external funding dependency to community-driven initiatives

Strategic Opportunities



Enhanced Coordination Role for RWAV

Potential to serve as primary coordinator for Victorian rural health workforce initiatives

Opportunity to leverage community and sector partnerships more effectively

Capability to organise cultural awareness training with qualified Indigenous educators

Platform to facilitate better integration between training organisations

Cultural Safety and Training Innovation

Development of comprehensive onboarding systems for registrars entering AMS settings

Creation of universal educational supports for supervisors

Implementation of mobile app technology for cultural safety training delivery

Establishment of mentorship programs modelled on RVTS successes

Community Engagement Strategies

Support for locally-driven workforce retention initiatives

Facilitation of social and professional integration events

Partnership development with councils and business communities

Promotion of community ownership in workforce solutions

Sector Integration and Best Practice Adoption

Documentation and scaling of RVTS support models

Coordination between colleges and training organisations

Standardisation of quality supports across all training pathways

Development of responsive, relationship-based support systems

Challenges and Considerations



Organisational Dysfunction

JCTS operational issues creating barriers to effective service delivery

Nepotism and poor HR practices affecting recruitment quality

Excessive bureaucracy and lack of responsiveness compared to effective models

Financial inefficiency in management structures

Workforce Sustainability

Difficulty recruiting and retaining qualified cultural educators

Competitive salary pressures from other organisations

Limited pool of experienced Indigenous health professionals

Geographic isolation affecting recruitment prospects

Systemic Coordination Gaps

Lack of universal standards for registrar onboarding and support

Poor communication between training organisations and placement sites

Absence of coordinated approach to cultural safety training

Inadequate support mechanisms for addressing workplace issues

Community Integration Barriers

Shift away from community-based workforce retention strategies

Over-reliance on external funding rather than local initiative

Loss of historical community engagement practices

Limited understanding of holistic community needs beyond health services

Action Items



Immediate Actions:

Connect with Julie Rogalski (former EVGPT CEO) for rural health coordination insights

Establish contact with Katrina Vassola (ACRRM State Manager, Bairnsdale office)

Review and analyse cultural safety training materials provided by Marlene

Investigate RVTS support models for potential sector-wide application

Strategic Development:

Explore RWAV's potential enhanced coordination role in Victorian rural health workforce

Develop mobile app prototype for cultural safety training content delivery

Map existing services and supports for doctors, registrars, and supervisors in AMS settings

Identify gaps in current support systems and develop remediation strategies

Partnership Building:

Facilitate connections between effective training models and struggling organisations

Engage community stakeholders in workforce retention initiatives

Develop relationships with local councils and business communities

Strengthen ties with Indigenous health service providers

Follow-up Activities:

Attend RWAV board presentation in Morwell and coordinate potential meeting

Provide comprehensive report on rural workforce challenges and coordination opportunities

Develop recommendations for RWAV's strategic positioning in sector coordination

Review uploaded materials and develop online resource platform

Integration with Strategic Vision



This consultation reinforces RWAV's strategic positioning as a coordination hub rather than a direct service provider. The emphasis on community-driven solutions and the potential for innovative technology applications aligns well with contemporary approaches to rural workforce development while respecting the fundamental importance of cultural safety and Indigenous self-determination in health service delivery. ”



He suggested RWAV and PHNs replicate this approach statewide through structured community partnership frameworks and micro-innovation grants
